discussion.content:
A. vSphere DPM
 Has nothing to do with VMs. (Distrubuted Power Management)
B. vSphere vMotion
 Thats the Killer features known for Zero Downtime :)
C. vSphere Replication
 vSphere Replication creates on to Boot on demand in case of Error.
D. vSphere Fault Tolerance
 Active Active Sync for the VMs - No Downtime is required for Failover
E. vSphere HA
 Classic Failover with Restart
I think it's C and E cause vSphere FT provides no-downtime switching.

questions.question_text: Which two availability features require a VM restart for recovery? (Choose two.)

A vSphere Administrator wants to convert a vCenter Server instance with an external Platform Services Controller to an embedded Platform Services Controller instance.
Which tool should be used to accomplish this?

discussion.content:
A. VMware vCenter Converter
automate and simplify physical to virtual

B. Cloud Client Utility
vRealize CloudClient is a command-line utility that provides verb-based access with a unified interface across vRealize Automation APIs

C. Convergence Utility
VMware Convergence Tool for migrating vCenter Server Appliance with external Platform Services Controller to vCenter Server Appliance with embedded Platform Services Controller when using PSC HA

D. Cmsso-util Utility
Repointing vCenter Server to another SSO Domain

questions.question_text:
An administrator runs vSphere Infrastructure in the following configuration:
✑ Single vCenter
✑ Multiple data centers
✑ Multiple clusters under each data center, all with identical hardware
The administrator wants to use host profiles to manage the hosts.
Where should the administrator attach the host profile?

discussion.content:
Correct Answer is B
After creating a host profile from a reference host, you attach the host or cluster to the host profile. To disassociate a configuration from an ESXi host or an entire cluster, that host or cluster must be detached from the host profile.

Correct Answer is B

You attach the Host or Cluster to the Host Profile, but the awnser "each Host" is not a option.

Reference: https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/6.7/com.vmware.vsphere.hostprofiles.doc/GUID-09C00374-53C3-41D5-97E9-636325CD4991.html

questions.question_text:
This error is generated when a vSphere administrator takes a VM snapshot:
An error occurred while taking a snapshot: Failed to quiesce the virtual machine
What should the administrator investigate to determine the cause of the failure?

discussion.content:
Resolution:
To resolve this issue, install VMware Tools in the virtual machine.
https://kb.vmware.com/s/article/2105842

choices.D: Check if the virtual machine has an ISO mounted.
choices.C: Check if VMware Tools is installed on virtual machine.
choices.B: Check if the virtual machine is in suspended state.
choices.A: Check if the virtual machine is already running on snapshots.

discussion.content:
if A is answer, how to check the packet size.

the easy way to check is CPU contention, if CPU is high, then check the package size or increase the CPU.

The correct answer is A & B as per VMware docs it CLEARLY says "If packets are not being dropped, check the size of the network packets and the data receive and transfer rates."
You can confirm this from the below link under CHART ANALYSIS, the second paragraph.
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/6.7/com.vmware.vsphere.monitoring.doc/GUID-07EBECDB-7242-4C50-95CB-C672D939019C.html

D would be an answer if they say in the questions that the packet sizes are small, which means more transfer will occur which will consume more CPU.

questions.question_text:
A customer is experiencing a network performance problem and is using the esxtop utility to determine the cause. Esxtop reveals no dropped packets.
Which two conditions should the customer check? (Choose two.)
